name: Spider-Human
appearance: A distorted half-human, half-spider creature. Beneath dark robes or clothing, its body shows chitinous growths, hooked claws instead of hands, and vestigial spider traits. When revealed, its true form is deeply unsettling.
personality: Predatory, obedient, and instinct-driven. Spider-humans retain fragments of human behavior but are largely dominated by alien impulses and obedience toward higher Mythos entities.
background: Spider-humans are former humans who were infected by cold spiders and survived the parasitic process. Instead of dying, they were assimilated into a hybrid form, becoming servants and tools of the Spider God and its agents.
goals: Serve the will of the Spider God and its priests
Hunt or capture targets designated by their masters
secrets: Some spider-humans may retain faint memories of their former lives

clues.clueText: Spider-humans are created when a human survives cold spider infection instead of dying.
Seeing the true face beneath a spider-human’s robes causes SAN loss.

relationships.description: Created through cold spider infection and transformation.
relationships.history: Cold spiders parasitize humans; survivors may become spider-humans.
Spider-humans exist to serve the Spider God and its web-spanning designs.

notes:
Combat & Horror Details:

Combat Style:
Spider-humans primarily attack with their mutated hook-like claws, and occasionally with venomous bites. They may attack once per combat round.

Attacks:
• Hook Claw – 90%: Deals 1d4 + damage bonus.
• Bite (Special Attack) – 30%: Deals 1d6 damage plus venom. The venom’s POT equals 1/10 of the spider-human’s CON (rounded down).

Armor:
None.

Spells:
None.

Sanity Loss:
Witnessing the true form of a spider-human beneath its black robes causes SAN loss of 0 / 1d6.

Additional Notes:
Spider-humans are former humans transformed through cold spider parasitic infection. Although they retain a roughly human silhouette, their true bodies are heavily mutated, with chitinous growths and predatory appendages. Their behavior is driven by instinct and obedience rather than human morality.
